note: Poor CYP2D6: codeine cannot be converted to morphine. Fluoxetine CYP2D6 inhibition is redundant. Interaction severity lower but codeine is also ineffective.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine blocks codeine-to-morphine conversion, causing analgesia failure and serotonin syndrome risk.
Ultra-rapid CYP2D6: excessive morphine production from codeine. Fluoxetine partially blocks this but interaction is unpredictable.
Intermediate CYP2D6: reduced codeine activation. Fluoxetine inhibition pushes patient closer to poor metabolizer phenotype.
Poor CYP2D6: paroxetine CYP2D6 inhibition redundant; codeine already ineffective as analgesic.
Extensive CYP2D6: paroxetine (strong inhibitor) blocks codeine activation; therapeutic failure.
Ultra-rapid CYP2D6: paroxetine may not fully block the excessive morphine generation; unpredictable.
Poor CYP2D6: tramadol active metabolite not formed. Serotonergic interaction still present but opioid component reduced.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine blocks tramadol activation + both are serotonergic. Dual risk.
Ultra-rapid CYP2D6: excessive active metabolite formation. Serotonin syndrome + respiratory depression risk very high.
Poor CYP2D6: reduced tramadol activation. Paroxetine inhibition redundant for CYP2D6. Serotonergic risk persists.
Extensive CYP2D6: bupropion inhibits tramadol activation + both lower seizure threshold.
Poor CYP2D6: hydrocodone to hydromorphone conversion minimal. Paroxetine inhibition less clinically relevant.
Ultra-rapid CYP2D6: paroxetine may partially attenuate excessive hydromorphone formation but interaction remains complex.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine reduces oxymorphone formation. Oxycodone has direct activity so impact is moderate.
Poor CYP2D6: oxymorphone not formed regardless. Fluoxetine inhibition of CYP2D6 irrelevant. Minimal change.
Poor CYP2D6: haloperidol already accumulates. Adding fluoxetine further inhibits residual metabolism + QT risk.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine inhibition raises haloperidol levels but from normal baseline; requires dose adjustment.
Poor CYP2D6: risperidone clearance already impaired. Paroxetine adds serotonergic effect on top of elevated levels.
Extensive CYP2D6: paroxetine inhibition raises risperidone levels; dose reduction can manage.
Poor CYP2D6: aripiprazole AUC already 80% higher. Fluoxetine inhibition compounds this.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine raises aripiprazole levels; halve aripiprazole dose per labeling.
Poor CYP2D6: tamoxifen cannot form endoxifen (active metabolite). Adding fluoxetine makes no difference—but tamoxifen is already ineffective.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine blocks endoxifen formation, reducing tamoxifen efficacy for breast cancer.
Paroxetine is the strongest CYP2D6 inhibitor; blocks tamoxifen activation. Associated with increased breast cancer mortality.
Poor CYP2D6: atomoxetine AUC 10x higher at baseline. Fluoxetine adds to already dangerous accumulation.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine inhibition raises atomoxetine levels 6-8x, converting patient to PM phenocopy.
Poor CYP2D6: nortriptyline levels already 3-4x elevated. Adding CYP2D6 inhibitor = cardiac toxicity risk.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine inhibition raises nortriptyline to toxic range. TDM required.
Poor CYP2D6: imipramine and desipramine (active metabolite) both accumulate. Paroxetine inhibition additive.
Extensive CYP2D6: bupropion strong inhibition raises desipramine levels 2-5x.
Poor CYP2D6: desipramine already toxic levels. Bupropion further inhibits residual CYP2D6 + seizure risk.
Poor CYP2D6: flecainide has narrow therapeutic index. Accumulation causes fatal arrhythmia.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine inhibition raises flecainide levels. Dose reduction and ECG monitoring needed.
Poor CYP2C19: clopidogrel activation already impaired. Omeprazole inhibition eliminates residual activation. Stent thrombosis risk.
Extensive CYP2C19: omeprazole reduces clopidogrel activation ~40%. Clinical significance debated.
Ultra-rapid CYP2C19: excess enzyme capacity may compensate for omeprazole inhibition.
Intermediate CYP2C19: already reduced activation. Omeprazole pushes to functional poor metabolizer.
Poor CYP2C19 + esomeprazole: clopidogrel essentially inactive. Consider prasugrel or ticagrelor.
Poor CYP2C19: even weaker CYP2C19 inhibitor (lansoprazole) has impact when patient already PM.
Poor CYP2C19: pantoprazole is weakest CYP2C19 inhibitor among PPIs. Still additive effect in PM.
Extensive CYP2C19: pantoprazole has minimal CYP2C19 inhibition. Preferred PPI with clopidogrel.
Poor CYP2C19: voriconazole AUC 4x higher. Phenytoin induces remaining CYP pathways. Bidirectional interaction amplified.
Extensive CYP2C19: voriconazole levels reduced by phenytoin induction. Dose increase needed.
Ultra-rapid CYP2C19: voriconazole cleared very rapidly. Phenytoin induction compounds this. Subtherapeutic antifungal levels.
Poor CYP2C19: escitalopram clearance already reduced. Omeprazole further competes for residual CYP2C19.
Extensive CYP2C19: adequate enzyme capacity for both substrates. Minimal clinical interaction.
Poor CYP2C19: N-desmethylclobazam (active metabolite) accumulates 5x. Adding CYP2D6 inhibitor creates dual pathway block.
CYP2C9 PM + VKORC1 sensitive: warfarin dose requirement very low (~1mg/day). Fluconazole CYP2C9 inhibition pushes to life-threatening bleeding.
Normal CYP2C9/VKORC1: fluconazole still strongly inhibits warfarin metabolism. Standard interaction.
VKORC1 resistant: warfarin dose requirement high. Even with fluconazole inhibition, patient has buffer before over-anticoagulation.
CYP2C9 IM + VKORC1 sensitive: already on very low warfarin dose. Any CYP2C9 inhibitor is extremely dangerous.
CYP2C9 PM: warfarin clearance already minimal. Amiodarone inhibition of CYP2C9/1A2 further compounding.
Normal PGx: amiodarone still significantly inhibits warfarin metabolism. Reduce warfarin 30-50%.
CYP2C9 PM: metronidazole inhibition of already minimal warfarin metabolism = critical bleeding risk.
CYP2C9 PM + VKORC1 sensitive: TMP-SMX inhibits CYP2C9 and reduces vitamin K-producing gut flora. Bleeding risk extreme.
CYP2C9 PM: phenytoin clearance severely impaired. Fluconazole inhibition of residual CYP2C9 = phenytoin toxicity (ataxia, nystagmus).
Normal CYP2C9: fluconazole still significantly raises phenytoin levels. TDM required.
HLA-B*1502 positive: carbamazepine contraindicated due to SJS/TEN risk. Adding lamotrigine (also SJS risk) is absolutely contraindicated.
HLA-B*1502 negative: carbamazepine SJS risk baseline level. Interaction still severe (enzyme induction reduces lamotrigine).
HLA-B*1502 positive: both carbamazepine and phenytoin carry SJS/TEN risk with this allele. Combination absolutely contraindicated.
HLA-B*1502 negative: complex bidirectional enzyme induction interaction. SJS risk at baseline level.
HLA-B*1502 positive: carbamazepine itself is contraindicated. Any combination is also contraindicated.
HLA-B*1502 positive: cross-reactivity between carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine for SJS/TEN.
HLA-B*1502 positive: phenytoin SJS/TEN risk. Combined with valproic acid protein displacement = amplified exposure.
HLA-B*1502 positive: both phenytoin and lamotrigine carry SJS risk. Combined use elevates risk.
Poor CYP2D6: methadone R-enantiomer clearance reduced. Fluoxetine inhibition of both CYP2D6 and CYP3A4 raises QT risk.
Ultra-rapid CYP2D6: methadone clearance rapid. Fluoxetine inhibition may actually stabilize levels closer to therapeutic.
Poor CYP2D6: propafenone exhibits nonlinear kinetics. In PM, beta-blocking activity prominent. Adding CYP2D6 inhibitor = cardiac toxicity.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine converts propafenone kinetics from linear to nonlinear. Significant toxicity risk.
Poor CYP2C19: diazepam N-demethylation impaired. Omeprazole competition for residual CYP2C19 further extends half-life.
Extensive CYP2C19: adequate enzyme capacity. Omeprazole competition clinically insignificant.
Poor CYP2C19: sertraline partially metabolized by CYP2C19. Reduced clearance + omeprazole inhibition raises levels.
Poor CYP2D6: both duloxetine and metoprolol are CYP2D6 substrates. Both accumulate in PM. Excessive beta-blockade + serotonergic effects.
Extensive CYP2D6: duloxetine inhibits metoprolol metabolism. Standard drug interaction.
Poor CYP2D6: venlafaxine O-desmethylvenlafaxine ratio altered. Both drugs accumulate.
Poor CYP2D6: clomipramine already elevated. Fluoxetine adds CYP2D6 inhibition + serotonergic interaction. Cardiac and serotonin toxicity.
Extensive CYP2D6: fluoxetine inhibition raises clomipramine levels significantly. Serotonin syndrome risk.
Poor CYP2C19: omeprazole levels higher but phenytoin primarily CYP2C9 substrate. CYP2C19 PM less relevant for phenytoin.
CYP2C9 PM: losartan is a prodrug activated by CYP2C9. In PM, losartan less effective; fluconazole makes it worse.
Extensive CYP2C9: fluconazole inhibition of losartan activation. Active metabolite E-3174 reduced.
CYP2C9 PM: celecoxib AUC already 2-3x higher. Fluconazole inhibition further compounds this. GI/CV toxicity risk.
Poor CYP2D6: donepezil levels elevated. Paroxetine further inhibits metabolism. Excessive cholinergic effects.
Extensive CYP2D6: paroxetine raises donepezil levels but within manageable range.
HLA-B*1502 positive: oxcarbazepine carries SJS risk (lower than carbamazepine). Combined with lamotrigine SJS risk, severity elevated.
HLA-B*1502 negative: baseline SJS risk. Pharmacokinetic interaction is mild.
Ultra-rapid CYP2D6: ondansetron cleared faster. Fluoxetine inhibition may actually normalize ondansetron levels.
Poor CYP2D6: metoprolol AUC 5x elevated at baseline. Paroxetine inhibition on top = severe bradycardia/hypotension.
Extensive CYP2D6: paroxetine raises metoprolol 4-6x by phenocopying PM. Significant bradycardia risk.
CYP2C9 PM: both warfarin and celecoxib are CYP2C9 substrates. Competitive inhibition in PM = massive warfarin elevation + celecoxib GI risk.
